Abstract: Influenza pandemics have historically posed significant threats to global health, with their origins often traced back to complex interactions between human, avian, and swine influenza viruses. This research delves into the genesis of influenza pandemics, focusing on the role of aquatic birds as natural reservoirs for influenza A viruses and the critical process of viral reassortment that facilitates the emergence of novel strains. The study also examines the impact of live bird markets as hotspots for viral transmission and reassortment, highlighting the intricate dynamics that contribute to the spillover of viruses into human populations. Drawing on data from the World Health Organization and incorporating insights from autobiographical accounts of pandemic responses, this paper aims to shed light on the pathways through which influenza viruses evolve into pandemic threats. By understanding these origins, the research underscores the importance of surveillance and preparedness strategies to mitigate the impact of future influenza pandemics.
